title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trust health service staff coronavirus
story: All along he has followed the best advice of our foremost experts on ­epidemics. They said that would evolve as the situation worsened — and yesterday it was toughened dramatically.National unity is key. We must take to heart the self-isolation and lockdowns — both for those already with symptoms and those without. Likewise the “advice” not to go to pubs, restaurants or cinemas.Our lives will be very dferent for months. Britain will barely resemble the country we love. But we can all play our part in seeing off this catastrophe, minimising the disease’s spread and giving the NHS every chance to save lives.The Sun will raise just one doubt:It still seems inconsistent that families must avoid non-essential social contact, but continue packing the children off to school. We know the NHS would be hit hardhealth workers stayed home to look after their kids. But a school skeleton staff could surely supervise them.Only the wartime generation has experienced a crisis this grave. We have to put our faith politically in the newly elected government tasked with facing it down — and the experts around them.Even more importantly we must trust our health service and back its magnicent and selfless staff. You can do that today by emailing iloveNHS@the-sun or by using the form below. We’ll print your messages.The NHS will need every ounce of support the nation can give, evenit just means dutully staying put in our homes.  THE six days since the Budget seem like ten years.Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s admirable debut last Wednesday is all but irrelevant. Its apparently huge bailouts to mitigate the virus will be nowhere near enough. Its growth forecasts are toast.Britain’s decisive response, including the Bank of England slashing the base rate hours earlier, was praised around the world. Others followed suit. But vastly more will now be needed.Evenit lasts no more than a few months — still a big— Covid- is a gargantuan shock to the global economy.Hundreds of thousands of healthy businesses here face oblivion. Their workers may face the dole. Major ­airlines could go bust within weeks.The Government will have to borrow staggering sums to keep them afloat — dishing out grants, tax breaks, business rates relief, interest-free loans, boosted sick pay and more.But we will add this: This is a ­calamity we must ALL face together.If corporations make staff take the pain while fatcat execs sail through it financially unscathed, there will be hell to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus advice pregnant women uk
story: PREGNANT women are warned to take extra care as the coronavirus crisis grips Britain.The UK government has now classed expectant mothers as those among the vulnerable group of society at risk of Covid-.Professor Chris Whitty, Englands Chief Medical Officer, said that including pregnant women in this group was a precautionary measure as experts are early in our understanding of this virus.And his deputy, Professor Jonathan Van-Tam, said its hoped that these new measures will reduce the infection rate and protect those at higher risk.He told the BBC: When it comes to this coronavirus, it is a new disease, its been with humans around the world for just a few months.We are being very precautionary in terms of the advice we are giving to pregnant women to increase their social distancing.We know that a whole range of normal infections are more serious in pregnancy and the advice were giving is extremely precautionary.Tap to see where COVID- is near you He added: The early signal, and it is only an early signal, is that the highest risk is only going to be towards the end of the third trimester, so from the th week, that kind of position in the pregnancy.But we are being very precautionary and saying that because we dont know enough about this disease yet.We havent got enough information on the disease in pregnant women, that the best thing to do is take a precautionary approach and advise social distancing and to identy that this is strongly advised for pregnant women as a whole group.According to the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists , the large majority of women will experience only mild or moderate symptoms.These include a cough, fever and shortness of breath.More severe symptoms, such as pneumonia, are widely described in older people and those with underlying conditions.However, they say that these symptoms could occur in pregnant women, and have advised healthcare professionals that these should be identied and treated promptly.So far, there has been just one reported case of a woman with Covid- who required mechanical ventilation at  weeks’ pregnant, following which she had an emergency caesarean section and made a good recovery, they noted.There has also been no reported deaths in pregnant women who have contracted the new coronavirus.Experts also say that there is currently no data to suggest that there is an increased risk of miscarriage or early pregnancy loss in relation to Covid-.They added that its considered unlikely that there will be congenital effects of the virus on foetal development.According to their advice, the professonial body said: There is also no evidence that the virus can pass to your developing baby while you are pregnant .It is therefore considered unlikely thatyou have the virus it will cause abnormalities in your baby.Some babies born to women with symptoms of coronavirus in China have been born prematurely.It is unclear whether coronavirus caused this or the doctors made the decision for the baby to be born early because the woman was unwell. As we learn about the risk of pre-term birth and coronavirus infection, we will update this information.As this is a new virus, there is limited evidence about managing coronavirus infection in those who have just given birth.However, there are no reports of women diagnosed with coronavirus during the third trimester of pregnancy having passed the virus to their babies while in the womb.Andyou have suspected or confirmed coronavirus at the time your baby is born, your baby will be tested for coronavirus.Based on the current government advice, you may be asked to self-isolateyou have symptoms of coronavirus, such as a high temperature or a new, continuous cough, or youve been tested positive for the illness.Pregnant women who have been advised to self-isolate should stay indoors and avoid contact with others for  days.The NHS guidance on self-isolation currently recommends people should:You may wish to consider online fitness routines to keep active, such as pregnancy yoga or Pilates.Pregnant women are advised not to attend maternity triage units or AE unless in need of urgent pregnancy or medical care.The RCOG said: If you have concerns about the wellbeing of yourself or your unborn baby during your self-isolation period, contact your midwe, or out-of-hours, your maternity team.They will provide further advice, including whether you need to attend hospital.If attendance at the maternity unit or hospital is advised, pregnant women are requested to travel by private transport, or arrange hospital transport, and alert the maternity triage reception once on the premises, prior to entering the hospital.As a precautionary approach, pregnant women with suspected or confirmed coronavirus when they go into labour, are being advised to attend an obstetric unit for birth.This way the baby can be monitored using continuous electronic fetal monitoring, and the mums oxygen levels can be monitored hourly.As this can only take place in an obstetric unit, where doctors and midwives are present, it is not currently recommended that you give birth at home or in a midwe led unit, where only midwes would be present.The experts also say that there is no evidence to suggest that you cannot give birth vaginally - or that youd be safer having a c-section.Therefore your birth plan should be followed as closely as possible based on your wishes.However,your respiratory condition suggested that urgent delivery would be needed, a caesarean birth may be recommended.The experts added: There is no evidence that women with suspected or confirmed coronavirus cannot have an epidural or a spinal block.However, the use of gas and air may increase aerosolisation and spread of the virus, so your maternity team will discuss all the options with you in early labour to ensure you are aware of the pain relief options available to you.The RCOG says that you should contact your midwe or antenatal clinic to inform them that you are currently in self-isolation for possible confirmed coronavirus and request advice on attending routine antenatal appointments.It is likely that routine antenatal appointments will be delayed until isolation ends.If your midwe or doctor advises that your appointment cannot wait, the necessary arrangements will be made for you to be seen.For example, you may be asked to attend at a dferent time, or in a dferent clinic, to protect other patients.If you have confirmed coronavirus infection, as a precautionary approach, an ultrasound scan will be arranged  days after your recovery, according to health officials.This  day period may be reduced as more information on how infected people are in recovery becomes available, they added.If you have recovered from coronavirus and tested negative for the virus before you go into labour, where and how you give birth will not be affected by your previous illness.Provided your baby is well and doesn’t require care in the neonatal unit, you will be kept together after you have given birth - so you can still have skin-to-skin contact.There are some reports from China which suggest women with confirmed coronavirus have been advised to separate from their baby for  days.However, this may have potential negative effects on feeding and bonding and women should discuss the risks and benefits with their doctor.Prof Van-Tam also said that women shouldnt stop title: all schools uk closed from friday coronavirus
story: SCHOOLS across the WHOLE of the UK will be closed after Friday as Britain desperately tries to contain the coronavirus outbreak.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson told MPs this afternoon that schools will be open on Friday as usual but then will shut until further notice for all children - except to those of key workers and vulnerable kids.The move comes two weeks before kids are meant to break up for the Easter break.And they may not reopen before the six-week summer break too.Boris Johnson said this evening: I can announce today, that after schools shut their gates from Friday afternoon, they will remain closed to most people, from further notice.Nurseries, private schools and further education colleges will follow suit, he said.A Level and GCSE exams will be cancelled too, the PM said.The Education Secretary also confirmed that free school meals will continue for everyone who needs it - likely in the form of supermarket vouchers.Boris told the nation this evening that the spread was slowing - but he would go further and fasterhe needed to in the coming days.This will be for all children except to those of key workers and children who are most vulnerable.The scientic evidence shows these settings are safe for this small number of children to continue attending.But asking others to stay away will go towards helping us slow the spread of this virus.One MP said that heads up and down the country were demanding schools shut down because they had run out of soap and sanitiser.And another headteacher said they were unable to provide kids with the proper levels of education they usually could.It comes after a petition demanding the Government “#closetheschools” amassed hundreds of thousands of signatures.It says: “We would like the government to at least consider closing schools colleges down in the coming weeks or as soon as possible, in addition to taking necessary actions to prevent further spread.“We would like the Government or Parliament to enforce this action due to the growing fear among parents and students that attend school.“The ability to focus or concentrate is affected in addition to the growing fears of the Corona-virus.“In our view, the government and health officials around the world are more reactive rather than proactive. title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: asthma coronavirus self isolate
story: As coronavirus is known to attack the respiratory system, asthma sufferers are now wonderingthe virus is something that they are at a higher risk of catching too.According the World Health Organization ,you have asthma, you may be more vulnerable to contracting the virus.People with asthma get respiratory infections that can trigger similar symptoms to coronavirus like shortness of breath and coughing.But, there is no definitive evidence to prove that anyone with asthma is at a greater risk of contracting the COVID-.Yet, it is still advised asthma sufferers take extra care when any kind of respiratory illness is spreading, not just coronavirus.Most people who catch coronavirus only suffer mild effects and are likely to be fine in the future.But for a small percentage of the public, it can be deadly, including those who already suffer from underlying health issues.The biggest threat coronavirus poses is to those with weaker immune systems, and long-term or chronic illnesses.Asthma, while not considered to be an underlying health issue, is still a condition to be aware of during this outbreak as sufferers already have breathing problems.This could lead to the virus causing an infection to the respiratory tract.Evenan asthma sufferer doesnt contract coronavirus, respiratory viruses like these can trigger symptoms which can lead to an asthma attack.It has been recommended that people with asthma should avoid unnecessary interactions.This has been labelled social distancing, which has been put in place to cut down the spread of the virus.According to Asthma UK, sufferers of the disease should:As there has been no proven scientic link between asthma and coronavirus, these measures have been put in place to keep people with asthma safe and prevent the likelihood of contracting the disease.The best thing to do for those with asthma is to keep your pump close by, avoid unneccesary human contact and to start a peak flow diary. title: france ban brits uk coronavirus lockdown made tougher
story: BRITISH nationals will be banned from Francethe UK fails to use the same radical coronavirus containment measures being enforced by EU countries.During a live TV address from Paris on Tuesday evening, French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe expressed extreme frustration that Britain was lagging behind in the war against the deadly illness.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesEveryone within the European Union must adopt coherent methods and processes to fight the epidemic, as in Italy, France and Spain, he said‘It goes without saying thatneighbouring states such as the United Kingdom spend too long continuing to avoid these containment measures, then we would have dficulty accepting British nationals who would move freely in their own country and then come to our country.Mr Philippe was speaking on the first day of a nationwide lockdown in his own country, which has seen major cities including Paris grind to a halt.Such a ban will cause huge problems for the millions of British nationals who have professional and personal links with France.The British make up the biggest foreign visitor group to Paris, which is normally the most popular tourist city in the world.While restrictions on movement and lestyle are growing every day in EU countries, post-Brexit Britain is perceived to be lagging behind.France has ordered bars and restaurants to shut down, for example, while in the UK managers can make their own decision.On Monday, President Emmanuel Macron pledged to put €billioninto the war against coronavirus.There are currently , police and gendarmes officers enforcing draconian restrictions, which include everybody needing an official document to leave the house.Fines for anyone caught without these ‘attestations’ will rise to the equivalent of around £ on Wednesday.Mr Macron said: Walking, meeting friends in the park or in the street will no longer be possible.It is a question of limiting as much as possible all contact beyond the home. All over French territory, in mainland France as well as overseas, only necessary journeys must remain necessary.He said people will only be permitted to leave their homes for necessary trips such as going to work or the supermarket.However, Macrons rules are much stricter than that of the UK.Brits have been told not to leave the house unless necessary and to work from home where possible, and avoid social contact.From tomorrow, the Government will no longer support mass gatherings either, meaning concerts and all major sporting events are likely to be cancelled.Cases in the UK have soared to , and  people have now died from the killer bug as the pandemic continues to rampage through the country.There are currently  people known to infected by Coronavirus in France, while  are dead and  in intensive care in hospitals which are struggling to cope.And UK foreign secretary Dominic Raab said Brits were not to travel anywhere outside the UK for at least  days to stop the spread of  COVID-.Mr Raab told the nation to stay put unless it is absolutely essential - cancelling all holidays and trips - as he updated the countrys travel advice this afternoon.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: female narwhals attracted biggest horns
story: And narwhal fellas like to wave their tusks about as “a sexual weapon” when fighting other males over females.Zackary Graham made the discovery after studying  years of horn size data compared to body size of  adult male narwhals.When comparing iniduals of the same age, sexually selected traits often exhibit disproportional growth - that is, for a given body size, sexually selected traits are often larger than expected in the largest iniduals.Importantly, they compared the growthof the tusk to the scaling relationship between body size and a trait that is unlikely to have sexual s. To do so, they used the tail of the narwhals, called the fluke.Zackary, of Arizona University, said: “The narwhal tusk is a sexually selected signal that is used during the male-male tusking contests.The information that the tusk communicates is simple: ‘I am bigger than you’.”The narwhal is a medium-sized species of whale with a large tusk that ies from in to more than ft — earning it the nickname the “unicorn of the seas”.In fact it is not a true tusk but an enlarged spiral-shaped canine tooth that pushes through the narwhal’s flesh.The findings were published online by the journal Biology Letters.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: In the first case, nine-month-old Cassian Coates was rushed to hospital by his worried parents because he had a cold and fever.His parents, Myroslava and Callum Caotes, were then stunned when staff put a “big sign up” near them which read “suspected case”.She said a nurse walked past them in Manchester and gave them the terrying news by saying: “Yeah, that’s you guys”.Cassian, who is just nine-months-old, was then assessed by a doctor who confirmed he had the symptoms and said: “Yeah, it’s the coronavirus strand.”The news of Cassians diagnosis came just hours before a baby at the James Paget University Hospital in Norfolk was confirmed to have the killer bug.The baby was one of three patients who have been diagnosed with COVID- at the hospital in Great Yarmouth and the trio remain in isolation.Describing the moment her son was diagnosed in Manchester, Mrs Coates told Sky News: “When we got to the hospital, we had to go through special measures and ring a certain number for them to let us in.The waiting room actually had a big sign up saying suspected case.“Me and my husband were like oh my God, then a nurse walked past and said yeah, thats you guys.“We went in, then the doctor came in with a mask on, did some basic checks, temperature, checked his ears and said yeah, its the coronavirus strand.”Mrs Coates, a mum-of-one, admitted she and her husband first laughed when they were told as they were in disbelief that her son had the killer bug.The family is now in self-isolation at home and she is racking her brains as to how Cassian caught the disease.She added: “We wondered where he caught it because my husband and I are both fine.“I did panic but I cannot express how fantastic and reassuring our GP was. story: SHOCKING footage shows a “coronavirus-riddled” bus passenger deliberately coughing and sneezing on a journalist on live TV.The disgusting clip, taken from a news report by Argentinian website Cronica, was filmed at a bus station in the country’s capital Buenos Aires.Correspondent Marco Bustamante was reporting on the exodus of foreign nationals ing to their home countries amid the virus outbreak when the incident occurred.As he spoke, the culprit approached him and accused him of lying before declaring “I have coronavirus”, Cronica reports.He can be seen leaping from his seat and walking towards the shocked reporter, coughing and sneezing in his direction.The vile assailant then grins and waves his victim away as he heads back to the bench.Cops were called and rushed to the scene, detaining and isolating the attacker, the website reported.It is not clearhe really was suffering from the deadly disease.South America has seen relatively low virus infection rates so far, but numbers are expected to rise.Argentina has had  confirmed cases, including two deaths.There have been more than , people infected by Covid- around the world, with over , deaths.Sadly the news report is not the first time someone has been filmed deliberately coughing on others since the outbreak began.An outraged Aussie commuter was videoed calling out a woman for purposely spluttering in his direction during a heated row about spreading the bug this month.The spat unfolded on a train in Sydney after a woman apparently let out a cough without properly covering her face.And just weeks ago Thai Airlines cabin crew were filmed tackling a passenger who was accused of deliberately coughing on staff.One airline employee holds the woman in a headlock as others rush to his aid and restrain her, pleading with her to “stay down”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince harry meghan markle urge public come together coronavirus
story: PRINCE Harry and Meghan Markle today urged the public to come together in the face of the coronavirus crisis in a fresh statement on Instagram.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex told their .million followers we are all in this together as the number of global coronavirus cases today surged past ,.The couple posted a quote on their Instagram today, saying: This moment is as true a testament there is to the human spirit.Accompanied by the couples monogrammed H and M, they shared an inspiring message on social media telling their followers to focus on the positive news around them.They said: These are uncertain times. And now, more than ever, we need each other. We need each other for truth, for support, and to feel less alone during a time that can honestly feel quite scary.They went on: How we approach each other and our communities with empathy and kindness is indisputably important right now. Over the coming weeks, this will be our guiding principle.We are all in this together, and as a global community we can support each other through this process – and build a digital neighbourhood that feels safe for every one of us.It comes as the couple ed to Canada this month after completing their final engagements as Royals.The Sussexes had dramatically announced they were quitting the Firm in January - with their last day settled for March  after negotiations with the Queen.And it has been claimed the couple and baby Archie, who is ten months, are now self-isolating in their luxury North American home.There are so many around the world who need support right now, who are working tirelessly to respond to this crisis behind the scenes, on the frontline, or at home. Our willingness, as a people, to step up in the face of what we are all experiencing with COVID- is awe-inspiring.This moment is as true a testament there is to the human spirit. We often speak of compassion.All of our lives are in some way affected by this, uniting each of us globally.How we approach each other and our communities with empathy and kindness is indisputably important right now.Over the coming weeks, this will be our guiding principle. We will be sharing information and resources to help all of us navigate the uncertainty: from posting accurate information and facts from trusted experts, to learning about measures we can take to keep ourselves and our families healthy, to working with organisations that can support our mental and emotional well-being.In addition, we will focus on the inspiring stories of how so many of you around the world are connecting in ways big and small to lt all of us up.We are all in this together, and as a global community we can support each other through this process – and build a digital neighbourhood that feels safe for every one of us.We look forward to sharing more over the days and weeks to come...Meghan said they are grateful, especially Harry, that they could spend time with his family before all this insanity began, an insider said.Meghan saidhas been in contact with the both his father and grandmother. He urged them to stay safe and to take extra precautions.The couple are currently keeping a social distance in a huge waterfront pile, costing £ million, on Vancouver Island.According to the same source, Harry feels a bit helpless and isolated out in the middle of nowhere, but is grateful that they are all together as a family.Meanwhile, Princess Beatrice has been forced to cancel her May wedding due to concerns around the virus.A Buckingham Palace spokesman confirmed: Princess Beatrice and Mr Mapelli Mozzi are very much looking forward to getting married but are equally aware of the need to avoid undertaking any unnecessary risks in the current circumstances.In line with government advice for the UK and beyond, the couple are reviewing their arrangements for th May.They are particularly conscious of government advice in relation to both the wellbeing of older family members and large gatherings of people. Therefore, the planned reception in the Buckingham Palace Gardens will not take place.The couple will carefully consider government advice before deciding whether a private marriage might take place amongst a small group of family and friends.The Queen was today pictured without gloves conducting her last few engagements at Buckingham Palace before she is expected to head to Windsor.The monarch is soon set to leave London and head to Windsor Castle amid the coronavirus crisis.Several royal events will be postponed including all garden parties at the palace and the annual Maundy Service at St George’s Chapel on th April will not go ahead.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sanders suspends campaign after latest defeat to joe biden on super tuesday iii
story: It was reported the radical Democratic Socialist ended his bid for the US presidency after being beaten by Biden, according to a Bloomberg News reporter.The Fidel Castro-praising politician suffered huge losses to Biden, who won Arizona, Florida and Illinois.However, his campaign aides refuted claims he called it quits on Twitter today.Sanders Communications Director Mike Casca described them as absolutely .The claims emerged after Axios noted his campaign has no active Facebook ads - the morning after his disappointing results in primary bids.Bernies campaign manager previously Faiz Shakir issued a statement saying he would be assessing his campaign.Shakir said last night did not go the way we wanted, after Bernie lost three states, according to Axios.The report noted former presidential hopefuls Pete Buttigieg and Michael Bloomberg deactivated their Facebook ads before pulling out of the race.Despite his numerous gaffes on the campaign trail, Bidens latest victory marks the third consecutive week he has piled up wins after South Carolina last month revived his once-weakened campaign.Sanders recent comments about Cuba probably doomed him there weeks ago, well before Bidens South Carolina surge.In a  Minutes interview on February , Sanders praised Cuban dictator Castro for his massive literacy program. The -year-old Vermont senator has continued to push on in the  presidential race despite a string of losses to Biden.The coronavirus pandemic has also impacted both Bernie and Bidens rallies as Americans are urged to avoid large gatherings.Last week, Sanders vowed to do everything in his power to stop Donald Trump in his six-minute televised address in Vermont.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mobile morgue westminster london coronavirus
story: A HUGE mobile mortuary has been swtly set up in London to cope with the number of bodies from the coronavirus pandemic.It comes as cases in the UK surged to , with  deaths, as the Prime Minister urged everyone to work from home.Westminster Public Mortuary has space for  bodies, but the expanded tent set up will see this almost doubled - as London becomes the worst hit.Today builders were seen at the site behind Westminster Coroners Court readying for a jump in expected victims.A Westminster council worker at the site today, said the refrigerated racked tent would double the councils capacity.He also said councils were building similar tents to expand capacity as much as possible in the pandemic.Adding: The tent will be up today and will be ready by the weekend.We hopefully wont ever need them. But you saw the numbers of what could happen, so we need to be prepared.A Westminster City Council spokesperson added: We have plans in place to increase the capacity of our mortuary at Horseferry Road as part of a London wide response to the Coronavirusoutbreak.This is a precautionary step and similar arrangements are made during any London wide response to incidents. We hope and trust that this will not be needed but it is sensible to prepare at this stage.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.London is braced to enter a lockdown within days - with extra travel restrictions for Brits in the capital.Sources close to City Hall say the Government is preparing a fresh bill to give them the power to stop gatherings, and keep Londoners inside.The over s, those who are pregnant, and anyone with underlying health conditionsshould try not to leave their homesthey can, and avoid crowded spaces immediately.This will continue for the “long haul” – likely weeks or months.And those with severe illnesses like cancermust start cocooning themselves in their homes and get food delivered in from this weekend.Earlier this week Boris Johnson said: Clearly what we’re announcing today is a very substantial change in the way we want people to live their lives, and I can’t remember anything like it in my letime.I don’t think there’s really been anything like it in peacetime.It’s a very considerable, psychological, behavioural change that we’re asking you, we’re asking the public, the nation to do.But I’ve absolutely no doubt that we can do it, that we can do it together.A team from Imperial College London, led by Professor Neil Ferguson, said the new tighter controls could limit deaths to around , - with the leading professor admitting the best case scenario would still see tens of thousands die.The country could be stuck in a state of permanent outbreak and lockdown until a vaccine is found - which is at least a year away - experts warned.Professor Ferguson, director of the MRC centre at Imperial, said yesterday the UK is three weeks behind Italy, warning there was no time to lose as the NHS will be overwhelmed many times over in the fight against COVID-.He added the government got the timing of the lockdown just about right as it became unavoidable to no longer take stronger action.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk school closures exams scrapped
story: EXAMS will not take place in May and June this year after fears the spread of coronavirus will increase over the next few days.Boris Johnson today announced students would not sit their exams as he confirmed schools across the country would close from Friday.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson today announced: We will not go ahead with assessments or exams and we will not be publishing performance tables this academic year.He added: I know not all of this is going to be easy. I am asking nurseries schools and colleges to be at the forefront our our national response to this crisis.Boris Johnson added: Exams will not take place as planned in May and June.The move comes two weeks before kids are meant to break up for the Easter break.The number of cases have today hit , as the death toll hit  in Britain.A nine-month-old boy in Manchester is just one of the latest cases reported this week while a baby in Norfolk was confirmed with the virus.The parents of Cassian, Myroslava and Callum Caotes, were then stunned when staff put a “big sign up” near them which read “suspected case”.Cassian, who is just nine-months-old, was then assessed by a doctor who confirmed he had the symptoms and said: “Yeah, it’s the coronavirus strand.”Meanwhile, the UK’s youngest coronavirus victim was last night named as -year-old Craig Ruston - as his devastated we paid an emotional tribute.The amazing father-of-two, from Kettering, Northants, who had motor neurone disease, succumbed to the killer bug in hospital yesterday.Boris Johnson this week announced drastic new measures in an attempt to slow the spread of the bug - with confirmed cases worldwide today topping , worldwide.The PM last night promised a £bn war-time bailout to stop coronavirus from wrecking the economy.His people’s bailout will be the biggest rescue package in peacetime.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus could leave thousands stuck
story: NewsCoronavirus could leave thousands stuck without DWP disabled benefitA charity has raised fears for people who are midway through an appeal for ESA while the DWP devotes its resources to dealing with the outbreakShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThousands of people who’ve failed fit-for-work tests face being “stuck” without benefits thanks to coronavirus, campaigners have warned. Welfare charity ZK claimed people who are already midway through the appeal system face being trapped while the DWP deals with the outbreak. Director Marc Francis told MPs on the Work and Pensions Committee: “We anticipate there are tens of thousands of people who are stuck in the ‘mandatory reconsideration’ stage for Employment and Support Allowance. We’re anticipating there’s going to be quite long delays in mandatory reconsiderations being completed. We can’t have a situation where people are left for months on end without being able to apply for that.”Employment and Support Allowanceis one of the main sickness and disability benefits, worth £. a week. But well over , people each month lodge an appeal after being refused the benefit in a fit-for-work test. The first stage of that appeal is an internal process called a mandatory reconsideration . Yet waiting times for an MR have shot up from an all-time low of six days last summer to  days in January.People can claim for Universal Credit, which replaced ESA, but ZK advise against it because it is dficult to go back to the old system once a claim has started. Campaigners also demanded the government halt all benefit reassessments of disabled people already in the system. The DWP announced this week it would halt face-to-face assessments of people for disability benefit for at least three months. But telephone or paper-based assessments may still go ahead. Ayaz Manji of mental health charity Mind added: “It’s a time where particularly now disabled people shouldn’t be experiencing shocks to their income. And we have an assessment process which is very unreliable.  There is a strong case for suspending those reviews altogether in the near future so we can safeguard people during this time.” Meanwhile charities warned people are being given a take it or leave it offer by the DWP midway through a full tribunal appeal - that was less than what they could eventually get. SNP MP Chris Stephens branded the practice like Deal or No Deal or a double glazing sale.And James Taylor of disability charity Scope said disabled people felt caught out. Eleanor Southwood, Chair of the Royal National Institute of Blind People, told MPs it was an enormous problem.

And she begged Boris Johnson to provide more protective equipment for doctors on the frontline of fighting the coronavirus pandemic.Her question came after reports that UK hospitals are beginning to run out of vital equipment needed to protect nurses and doctors from catching coronavirus from infected patients. Meanwhile, Boris Johnson vowed to ramp up COVID- testing to , people per day within four weeks after anger that not all NHS staff could get a test. NHS staff have said they are unable to get hold of some face masks and other specialist personal protective equipmentwhich is needed to prevent them falling ill. Dr Allin-Khan said: Mr NHS colleagues on the frontline are already stressed with the pressure they face. We are in unprecedented times, I would like to know, where was the forward planning for PPE for our NHS and care staff  Where is the testing for medics  Why are waiting so long for mass testing  And why are social distancing measures merely just suggestions   Prime Minister it is right that we have all put party loyalty aside to work together during this time of national crisis, but we must scale up the response. Without good leadership, the people in this country will start to panic. There must be no more delay, the time to act is now. Mr Johnson said he completely agreed as he thanked Dr Allin-Khan for the work she does in the NHS. He added: I can tell her we have stockpiles of PPE equipment and we are proceeding in accordance with the best scientic advice. And it is the timeliness of those measures which are vital in combatting this epidemic. In fact, that is how you save lives, and I am delighted the UKs approach as been commended not just by Neil Ferguson of Imperial College today, but also by the World Health Organisation.The issue was also raised by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who asked Mr Johnson to explain why the healthcare staff werenapost being prioritised for testing.Mr Johnson said the government is prioritising testing of NHS staff. It may be of the interest of the house to know that we are getting closer to delivering a test that will let people knowthey have the disease.

title: coronavirus needs radical cure tories
story: NewsopinionCoronavirus needs a radical cure. The Tories need to take a big, deep snf of socialismBailing out billionaires might save businesses, says Fleet Street Fox. But people drive the economy, and theyre the ones who need helpShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email When last weekaposs Budget included a £bn deal to beat coronavirus, the headlines screamed: aposDr Feelgood to the Rescueapos.Today, after a £bn business bailout, itaposs the aposkiss of leapos. What no-one appears to have noticed is that the disease has got  times more expensive in the space of a week, and itaposs still in the post. We have had more than  months’ warning of the tidal wave coming our way. To start with, it was dismissed as just another flu, then blamed on bats, and finally an economic headache for eBay traders alone.But we were thick, and we were slow. Today that wave is roaring up the Thames, where after sucking a few poor souls to an early grave it’s going to wipe out those bits of the City still at work.Our economyaposs biggest contributors are services, manufacturing, construction, and tourism. Theyaposre all in shutdown. The governmentaposs big idea is to save them by bailing out the bosses - big and small - but they are ignoring the real problem. The vast majority of us may outlive the virus, but every single survivor is going to be violently mugged afterwards. The Prime Minister and Chancellor say it’s a bump in the road and we’ll be over it in  months. Medics say it’s more likely to be - months. Imperial College London says we won’t be in the clear for  months, or as long as it takes until there is a vaccine. If £bn was all it took when they thought there’d be a couple of weeks of it, and £bn had to be magicked up for  months, then the back of this beermat says that for a year and a half you’re looking at £. TRILLION of government bailout.Or four times what the banking crash cost us in . And remember - that’s just for businesses. Never mind the knock-on costs of healthcare, unemployment and sickness benefit, lost tax revenue and an economy that needs restarting.  It’s also a conservative estimate, considering our annual GDP is at the moment £.tn. Of course, it won’t be next year.After the -month mortgage holiday, the mortgage still has to be paid. After the government-backed, low-interest loan, it has to be ed, with interest. And after you’ve handed out a load of cash to every business owner from Richard Branson down to the local pub landlord, you may find they did not use it in the manner you hoped.The Daily Mail’s economic editor Alex Brummer wrote today:  “The lack of directly-paid support for employees, as outlined above, may prove to be an economic and political mistake. Relying on the kindness of bosses to keep paying wages on borrowed money, for a long time, is placing too much trust in their hands.” He added: A further package of measures which directly places cash into the pockets of British citizens would feel more real than promises of mortgage holidays and access to benefits.”Hooo-weee. Is this a call for a universal basic income I see before me, and in the Daily Mail of all places   But suddenly, the sort of radical socialism even Jeremy Corbyn didn’t have the blind optimism to put in his manesto is looking like a credible idea. There is no other way for the nation to get through an indefinite period of economic shutdown. The average Brit owes £, on credit cards. Mortgage holidays mean the banks will lose billions of guaranteed income. Rent holidays mean landlords default on mortgages, and we all stop servicing our debts the whole Tower of Banking Babel will fall. If staff are paid, rates are eased and tax takes a holiday, businesses can be mothballed. But customers cannot hibernate from this crisis -staff stop being paid, they stop being customers where. Take nursery schools. Fees are paid in advance for each term, so staff get paid regardless of how few toddlers turn up. But the new term starts on April , and how many parents, then, will be sending their children  How many nursery staff will still be in a job in a month’s time, and how many parents will be unable to go back to work   Fighting coronavirus is hard enough. But the real issue is how people get back on their feet afterwards. Chicken soup might get you out of bed, but it won’t pay the bills. If you don’t have a job, are on unpaid leave, are one of the .m self-employed whose savings just went up in smoke, you won’t be able to patronise the pub, shops and other businesses that just reopened.And the chances are this won’t be a -month thing. In China, factories are reopening, but m in-country migrants that form a massive part of its workforce havenapost turned up. When they do, there is a very real risk of a new wave of infections, and a new lockdown. In , the Spanish flu showed its head early in the year then ed with a vengeance in winter. If covid- does the same, we could be facing repeated global shutdowns until NEXT spring. If last weekaposs £bn looks puny and ineffective now, imagine how piddling £bn will look by then. Boris Johnson’s fiscal stimulus is, at present, the equivalent of offering half a paracetamol to someone who needs a ventilator. Itaposs just not enough. Itaposs not aposwhatever it takesapos, because what it is taking is the piss.At Prime Ministeraposs Questions today Labour MP Kevin Brennan said: On the matter of aposwhatever it takesapos, it takes more than a  word slogan, is what I would say to the Prime Minister. And in this case it actually takes a bit of war socialism we need to get money into the pockets of the workers. Has he seen Early Day Motion , which I proposed, about bringing in a temporary universal basic income to support workers and get money where it’s actually needed The PM replied: I hear the honourable gentleman loud and clear… and of course that is one of the ideas that will certainly be considered.First the Mail , and now this. A Thatcherite, Eurosceptic, Commie-bashing Tory PM, saying heaposs considering a universal basic income. Well Iaposll be...Of the  MPs who have signed that motion so far, none are Tory or Lib Dem. But that will change, when they start to see the price of not doing it.With a guaranteed amount in the bank every month, people can still feed their families. They can pay some,not all, of rent and mortgage costs, and when the shutdown ends theyaposll have the wherewithal to begin spending again. The government, too, wonapost have an expensive backlog of benefit claims to deal with. The only way for a nation to keep its head above water is for its citizens to each have a le jacket. The government is already the insurer of last resort, and faces a bill of trillions to mop up this mess. To abandon a single inch of its duty would be to destroy us, and it.Butit were to pay each of the .m households in Britain £, tomorrow, it would cost just £bn. Suddenly, radical socialism is cheap and reasonable. Even to Tories,theyaposre not too thick and slow to do the maths this time.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOfficials are braced for coronavirus lockdown measures to be ramped up in London within days, the Mirror understands. Multiple sources expect restrictions to be drastically tightened in the coming days as COVID- races ahead in the capital. Emergency laws to be introduced to Parliament tomorrow will include powers to close premises and restrict or prohibit events and gatherings anywhere in the UK,the government chooses to. The Coronavirus Bill will also allow the government to limit activity in any place, vehicle, train, vessel or aircraft - leading to fears there could be restrictions on public transport.Whitehall sources today told the Mirror lockdown-style measures in London - which Boris Johnson admitted is a few weeks ahead of the rest of the country - are imminent.But the exact timing and exact shape of any measures have not been decided. A senior Downing Street source vehemently denied anything had been decided. The governmentaposs advisory group SAGE was meeting from pm today to examine next steps. Unconfirmed reports in The Spectator suggest the current rules on avoiding pubs, clubs and unnecessary social contact - so far voluntary - could be made mandatory. No sources aposfirmlyapos told The Sun there would not be lockdown style measures today or tomorrow. Sources close to London mayor Sadiq Khanaposs office said they expect a tightening of restrictions in the capital in the coming days. However, the shape of any possible measures was unclear. City Hall sources criticised the lack of information from the Government. One said: We have not heard anything on this - this lack of information doesn’t sound like the best way to govern during a national emergency. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman today did not rule out a tightening of restrictions in the capital in future. AskedLondon was going to be locked down, he said: It’s a question of what you mean by that. In terms of the measures that we’re taking, we’ve always said they’ll always be based on the latest and the best scientic advice including from the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientic Advisor. Askedpeople may end up not allowed out of their homes unless they have paperwork to show a legitimate reason, like in France, Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: We’ve set out the steps which we think are necessary at this point in time. But we will be guided by scientic and medical advice to ensure we take the right steps to protect the public.”

story: NewsBrave girl, , has never eaten and vomits every day due to undiagnosed conditionBella Cole, from Great Baddow, Essex, can only get the nutrients she needs by being fed milk through a tube for  hours every night - but she still vomits every single dayShareCommentsByLouise Lazell:,  MAR NewsThe toddler has to be fed through a tube every night " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA little girl who is nearly four years old has never had anything to eat. Bella Cole, from Great Baddow in Essex, can only get the nutrients she needs through a tube which is connected to her small intestine for  hours every night to slowly feed her milk.But throughout the night and day, the toddler is regularly sick, throwing up stomach acid around ten times, Essex Live reports.There is no diagnosed medical reason for why Bella vomits daily, with doctors initially having thought she was suffering a bad case of reflux. But itaposs now thought she has a deep rooted aversion, having never had a positive experience of eating or drinking. Now her parents, who knew something wasnapost right ever since she was a few weeks old, are trying to raise the funds for treatment which could transform her le. Her mum, Philipa Rabbitts, has described the anguish which comes with feeding her daughter, who was born premature at  weeks. She was born weighing just four pounds  ounces, she was a little dot, the -year-old said. They said she was fine and we got discharged but at about two or three weeks old she wasn’t gaining any weight and was vomiting all the time and not eating.  After her parents took her to AE when she was six weeks old, she was put on an NG tube, which goes through the nose, past the throat and down into the stomach to feed her milk - but she still vomited everything back up. We were in and out the hospital with her all the time, Philipa says. After enduring a vicious cycle of constant feeding and vomiting for a year, Bellaaposs parents eventually took her to Addenbrookeaposs Hospital in Cambridge to have a dferent tube put into her small intestine. This bypasses the stomach, but still gives her nutrients. But because the small intestine isnapost a storage organ, it canapost expand, so Bella has to be fed very slowly for  hours overnight by a pump. And she is still frequently sick, to the extent that it has become normal for her and her family. The main time she vomits is at night, at first we didn’t sleep at all,” Philippa continued. It’s weird but it is so normal for us now, which it shouldn’t be. I don’t even hear her sometimes. I don’t always wake up when she does and she tells me. If it’s a bad episode then we wake up.  She will just be sick and say mummy I have been sick. It is normal to her but it shouldn’t be normal. Now it is getting normal we have got to stop the sickness for her to eat or she might never be able to. Philipa and Bellaaposs father, Matthew Cole, are now hoping to seek treatment privately to have another procedure to into her stomach. But with a -month waiting list on the NHS, they need £, to go to a specialist clinic in Austria to help her get off the tube.  Her vomit can be yellow and clear but sometimes there is blood in her vomit where she ruptures the blood vesselsshe has been strained, Philipa said. That’s why we can’t wait a year for the NHS to do the operation, it’s not fair on her. Because of an undiagnosed genetic condition, Bella is also very small and it took her a little bit longer to walk and talk because of the developmental delay. But despite everything, Bella, who now has a nine-month-old brother, Teddy, is always smiling. Bearing in mind she has only been talking a year, she is a massive character, Philipa continued. She’s so happy, she’s a typical three and a half year old, trying to get her own way and considering she has a few issues, she is a very happy child. Everyone knows her where we live in Great Baddow. She didnapost walk or talk until she was two and a half but since then she has come on so far. She grows but really slowly, her brother is nine months old and wearing nine to twelve month old clothes and I can put them on her. With everything up in the air with coronavirus, Bellaaposs parents are concerned that the operation, scheduled for April  at the No Tube Clinic in Austria, could be jeopardised. They have made the decision to pull Bella out of preschool to make sure she stays healthy enough to go. It is essential that Bella can get to the clinic before she turns five, the maximum age at which the clinic can accept children. There is a  percent success rate for weaning tube-dependent children off the tube - which Philipa and Matthew hope will change their daughteraposs le. For her sake, we want her to eat, Philippa says. It would mean everything to us just to get her to eat and get that tube off her. It restricts her because she canapost run around because of how heavy it is. We have to change her tube too and now she is more aware of what is happening. Itaposs heartbreaking for us to have to pin her down and change the tube. She says aposno mummy, no milkapos because she knows as soon as it is in her she is going to vomit. Even daily meal times have become dficult, as Bella can’t sit and eat a meal with her mum, dad and brother. Thankfully at pre-school, the staff all make sure that Bella is never left out and joins in at snack time, evenshe doesn’t eat.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Brit couples say their dream weddings are aposin limboapos with guests already cancelling amid coronavirus fears.Countries around the world have tightened border controls, imposed travel bans and locked down cities. And couples who have weddings planned in the coming months are unsure whether to cancel, postpone or leave arrangements in place - although some guests have already dropped out. Elisha Deol and her fiance Ronak Shah were set to have a Hindu wedding at the Oshwal Centre in Potters Bar, Hertfordshire, followed by a reception at the Savoy hotel next month.The wedding was going to cost them about £, in total, the BBC reports. But guests from around the world - including Kenya, Canada and the US - have cancelled already. The couple, from London, say they are in the process of contacting suppliers to enquire about refunds. Lauren Maitland and her fiance Charlotte Armitage are still hoping their wedding will go ahead in May, but will aposwait and seeapos. The happy couple, from St Ives in Cambridgeshire, plan to tie the knot at The Whitby Abbey in Yorkshire. But both are worried about their parents and other guests. Ms Maitland told the BBC: My mum has recently had a surgical procedure carried out on her heart and is recovering, while my granddad is  years old. Charlotte worries about her own parents daily too.  Beyond that, weaposre nervous of large public gatherings being cancelled which would mean our ceremony couldnapost go ahead, or indeed so many people having to self-quarantine meaning that the reception at Whitby Pavilion canapost go ahead. We also have friends and family travelling from Australia, New Zealand, Switzerland, Germany and the USA. Weaposre very nervous they wonapost be able to travel. The couple say they have insurance and that while their wedding is important, their friends and family are more important to them.
